Labeling Schemes with Queries

We study the question of â€œhow robust are the known lower bounds of labeling schemes when one increases the number of consulted labelsâ€. Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be a function on pairs of vertices. An fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling scheme for a family of graphs â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F labels the vertices of all graphs in â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F such that for every graph Gâˆˆâ„±ğºâ„±G\in{\cal F}italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_F and every two vertices u,vâˆˆGğ‘¢ğ‘£ğºu,v\in Gitalic_u , italic_v âˆˆ italic_G, the value fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by merely inspecting the labels of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v.

This paper introduces a natural generalization: the notion of fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries, in which the value fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by inspecting not only the labels of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v but possibly the labels of some additional vertices. We show that inspecting the label of a single additional vertex (one query) enables us to reduce the label size of many labeling schemes significantly. In particular, we show that to support the distance function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees as well as the flow function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node general graphs, Oâ¢(logâ¡n+logâ¡W)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘ŠO(\log n+\log W)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_W )-bit labels are sufficient and necessary, where Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is the maximum (integral) capacity of an edge. We note that it was shown that any labeling scheme (without queries) supporting either the flow function on general graphs or the distance function on trees, must have label size Î©â¢(log2â¡n+logâ¡nâ¢logâ¡W)Î©superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Š\Omega(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Î© ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W ). Using a single query, we also show a routing labeling scheme in the fixed-port model using Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels, while the lower bound on the label size of any such routing labeling scheme (without queries) is Î©â¢(log2â¡n/logâ¡logâ¡n)Î©superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›\Omega({\log^{2}n}/{\log\log n})roman_Î© ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ). We note that all our labeling schemes with queries have asymptotically optimal label size.

We then show several extensions. In particular, we show that our labeling schemes with queries on trees can be extended to the dynamic scenario by some adaptations of known model translation methods. Second, we show that the study of the queries model can help with the traditional model too. Finally, we turn to a non-distributed environment and first translate known results on finding NCA to supporting distance queries. We then use the above to show that one can preprocess a general weighted graph using almost linear space so that flow queries can be answered in almost constant time.

1 Introduction

Background:

Network representations play a major role in many domains of computer science, ranging from data structures, graph algorithms, and combinatorial optimization to databases, distributed computing, and communication networks. In most traditional network representations, the names or identifiers given to the vertices betray no useful information, and they serve only as pointers to entries in the data structure, which forms a global representation of the network. Recently, quite a few papers studied methods for representing network properties by assigning informative labels to the vertices of the network (see e.g., [43, 9, 32, 39, 51, 5, 24]).

Let fğ‘“fitalic_f be a function on pairs of vertices (e.g., distance). Informally, the goal of an fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling scheme is to label the vertices of a graph GğºGitalic_G in such a way that for every two vertices u,vâˆˆGğ‘¢ğ‘£ğºu,v\in Gitalic_u , italic_v âˆˆ italic_G, the value fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) (e.g., the distance between uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v) can be inferred by merely inspecting the labels of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v.

Of course, this can be done trivially using labels that are large enough (e.g., every label includes the description of the whole graph). Therefore, the main focus of the research concerning labeling schemes is to minimize the amount of information (the sizes of the labels) required. Informally, an fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling scheme can be viewed as a way of distributing the graph structure information concerning fğ‘“fitalic_f to the vertices of the graph, using small chunks of information per vertex.

This paper introduces the notion of fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries which generalizes the notion of fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling schemes. The idea is to distribute the global information (relevant to fğ‘“fitalic_f) to the vertices, in such a way that fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by inspecting not only the labels of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v but possibly the labels of some additional vertices. We note that all the constructions given in this paper calculate fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) by inspecting the labels of three vertices (uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v above, and some wğ‘¤witalic_w). That is, given the labels of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v, we first find a vertex wğ‘¤witalic_w and then consult its label to derive fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ).

Our paper demonstrate that the task of distributing the graph structure to the vertices using short labels is very sensitive to the model used. In particular, in order to calculate fâ¢(u,v)ğ‘“ğ‘¢ğ‘£f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ), if one is allowed to consult the labels of three vertices instead of two, then the sizes of the labels can drop considerably, in orders of magnitude. Moreover, our query labeling schemes can be obtained using simple methods. This turns out to be useful, when we go back to the traditional model (without queries) and apply ideas from one of our methods to construct a new result in the traditional model.

Most previous research concerning distributed network representations considered the static scenario, in which the topology of the underlying network is fixed. However, recent papers tackle the more difficult task of labeling dynamic networks in a distributed fashion. Such labeling methods should, of course, be dynamic too. We show that the effect of introducing a query to the dynamic case is similar to the effect on the static case. That is, we modify the model translation methods of [38] and [42], and then use them to extend our static labeling schemes with queries on trees, to the dynamic scenario. We then show that the sizes of the resulted schemes are smaller than those of the schemes for the older model. The reduction in the label size is similar to the reduction in the static case.

Finally, we show that our methods are also useful in the non-distributed environment.

Related work:

In this subsection we mostly survey results concerning labeling schemes (with no queries). However, let us first mention an area of research (namely, overlay and Peer to Peer networks) that may serve as a practical motivation for our work, and for some other studies concerning labeling schemes. We stress, though, that the main motivation for this paper is theoretical.

When the third vertex wğ‘¤witalic_w (mentioned above) is near by to uğ‘¢uitalic_u, it may be quite cheap for uğ‘¢uitalic_u to access the main memory at wğ‘¤witalic_w, sometimes even cheaper than consulting the disk at uğ‘¢uitalic_u itself. See, for example [47, 37]. Indeed, some of our schemes below are based on such a â€œnear byâ€ wğ‘¤witalic_w. Even when wğ‘¤witalic_w is remote, accessing it may be cheap in some overlay networks. The main overhead there is finding wğ‘¤witalic_w (which can be done in our constructions by uğ‘¢uitalic_u using vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s label) and creating the connection to it. Such models are presented explicitly, e.g. in [34, 16, 2, 54], where such remote accesses are used to construct and to use overlay data structures. Famous overlay data structures that can fit such models appear for example in [56, 63, 48, 26, 49]. In some of these overlay networks, a vertex wğ‘¤witalic_w is addressed by its contents. This may motivate common labeling schemes that assume content addressability.

Implicit labeling schemes were first introduced in [11, 12, 43]. Labeling schemes supporting the adjacency and ancestry functions on trees were investigated in [43, 9, 44, 7, 8].

Distance labeling schemes were studied in [50, 40, 32, 31, 29, 44, 59, 18, 4]. In particular, [50] showed that the family of nğ‘›nitalic_n vertex weighted trees with integer edge capacity of at most Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W enjoys a scheme using Oâ¢(log2â¡n+logâ¡nâ¢logâ¡W)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘ŠO(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W )-bit labels. This bound was proven in [32] to be asymptotically optimal.

Labeling schemes for routing on trees were investigated in a number of papers [55, 62, 15, 21, 23] until finally optimized in [24, 25, 61]. For the designer port model, in which the designer of the scheme can freely enumerate the port numbers of the nodes, [24] shows how to construct a routing scheme using labels of Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees. In the adversary port model, in which the port numbers are fixed by an adversary, they show how to construct a routing scheme using labels of Oâ¢(log2â¡n/logâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n/\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ) bits on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees. In [25] they show that both label sizes are asymptotically optimal. Independently, a routing scheme for trees using (1+oâ¢(1))â¢logâ¡n1ğ‘œ1ğ‘›(1+o(1))\log n( 1 + italic_o ( 1 ) ) roman_log italic_n-bit labels was introduced in [61] for the designer port model.

Two variants of labeling schemes supporting the nearest common ancestor (NCA) function in trees appear in the literature. In an id-NCA labeling schemes, the vertices of the input graph are assumed to have disjoint identifiers (using Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits) given by an adversary. The goal of an id-NCA labeling scheme is to label the vertices such that given the labels of any two vertices uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v, one can find the identifier of the NCA of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v. Static labeling schemes on trees supporting the separation level and id-NCA functions were given in [51] using Î˜â¢(log2â¡n)Î˜superscript2ğ‘›\Theta(\log^{2}n)roman_Î˜ ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n )-bit labels. The second variant considered is the label-NCA labeling scheme, whose goal is to label the vertices such that given the labels of any two vertices uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v, one can find the label (and not the pre-given identifier) of the NCA of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and vğ‘£vitalic_v. In [5] they present a label-NCA labeling scheme on trees enjoying Î˜â¢(logâ¡n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(\log n)roman_Î˜ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels.

In [39] they give a labeling scheme supporting the flow function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node general graphs using Î˜â¢(log2â¡n+logâ¡nâ¢logâ¡W)Î˜superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Š\Theta(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Î˜ ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W )-bit labels, where Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is the maximum capacity of an edge. They also show a labeling scheme supporting the kğ‘˜kitalic_k-vertex-connectivity function on general graphs using Oâ¢(2kâ¢logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘˜ğ‘›O(2^{k}\log n)italic_O ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n )-bit labels. See [30] for a survey on (static) labeling schemes.

Most of the research concerning labeling schemes in the dynamic settings considered the following two dynamic models on tree topologies. In the leaf-dynamic tree model, the topological event that may occur is that a leaf is either added to or removed from the tree. In the leaf-increasing tree model, the only topological event that may occur is that a leaf joins the tree.

A labeling schemes for the ancestry relation in the leaf-dynamic tree model is given in [19] using Oâ¢(n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(n)italic_O ( italic_n )-bit labels. They assume that once a label is given to a node it remains unchanged. Therefore, the issue of updates is not considered even for the non distributed setting. Other labeling schemes are presented in the above paper assuming that clues about the future topology of the dynamic tree are given throughout the scenario.

The study of dynamic distributed labeling schemes was initiated in [42, 41]. In [42], a dynamic labeling scheme is presented for distances in the leaf-dynamic tree model with Oâ¢(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) label size and Oâ¢(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) amortized message complexity, where nğ‘›nitalic_n is the current tree size. Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximate distance labeling schemes (in which, given two labels, one can infer a Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximation to the distance between the corresponding nodes) are presented [41]. Their schemes apply for dynamic models in which the tree topology is fixed but the edge weights may change.

Two general translation methods for extending static labeling schemes on trees to the dynamic setting are considered in the literature. Both approaches fit a number of natural functions on trees, such as ancestry, routing, label-NCA, id-NCA etc. Given a static labeling scheme on trees, in the leaf-increasing tree model, the resulting dynamic scheme in [42] incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) in both the label size and the communication complexity. Moreover, if an upper bound nfsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘“n_{f}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the final number of vertices in the tree is known in advance, the resulting dynamic scheme in [42] incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of Oâ¢(log2â¡nf/logâ¡logâ¡nf)ğ‘‚superscript2subscriptğ‘›ğ‘“subscriptğ‘›ğ‘“O(\log^{2}n_{f}/\log\log n_{f})italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_log roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in the label size and only Oâ¢(logâ¡n/logâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\log n/\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ) in the communication complexity. In the leaf-dynamic tree model there is an extra additive factor of Oâ¢(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) to the amortized message complexity of the resulted schemes.

In [38], it is shown how to construct for many functions kâ¢(x)ğ‘˜ğ‘¥k(x)italic_k ( italic_x ), a dynamic labeling scheme in the leaf-increasing tree model extending a given static scheme, such that the resulting scheme incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of Oâ¢(logkâ¢(n)â¡n)ğ‘‚subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘›O(\log_{k(n)}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ) in the label size and Oâ¢(kâ¢(n)â¢logkâ¢(n)â¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘›ğ‘›O(k(n)\log_{k(n)}n)italic_O ( italic_k ( italic_n ) roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ) in the communication complexity. As in [42], in the leaf-dynamic tree model there is an extra additive factor of Oâ¢(log2â¡n)ğ‘‚superscript2ğ‘›O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) to the amortized message complexity of the resulted schemes. 1.1 Our contribution

We introduce the notion of fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries that is a natural generalization of the notion of fğ‘“fitalic_f-labeling schemes. Using this notion we demonstrate that by increasing slightly the number of vertices whose labels are inspected, the size of the labels decreases considerably. Specifically, we inspect the labels of 3 vertices instead of 2, that is, we use a single query. In particular, we show that there exist simple labeling schemes with one query supporting the distance function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees as well as the flow function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node general graphs with label size Oâ¢(logâ¡n+logâ¡W)ğ‘‚ğ‘›ğ‘ŠO(\log n+\log W)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_W ), where Wğ‘ŠWitalic_W is the maximum (integral) capacity of an edge. (We note that the lower bound for labeling schemes without queries for each of these problems is Î©â¢(log2â¡n+logâ¡nâ¢logâ¡W)Î©superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘Š\Omega(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Î© ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W ) [32, 39].) We also show that there exists a labeling scheme with one query supporting the id-NCA function on nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees with label size Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ). (The lower bound for schemes without queries is Î©â¢(log2â¡n)Î©superscript2ğ‘›\Omega(\log^{2}n)roman_Î© ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) [51].) In addition, we show a routing labeling scheme with one query in the fixed-port model using Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels, while the lower bound (see [25]) for the case of no queries is Î©â¢(log2â¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)Î©superscript2ğ‘›ğ‘›\Omega(\frac{\log^{2}n}{\log\log n})roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ). We note that all the schemes we introduce have asymptotically optimal label size for schemes with one query. The matching lower bound proofs are straightforward in most of the cases, and we present the proofs in the remaining cases. Moreover, most of the results are obtained by simple constructions, which strengthens the motivation for this model.

We then show several extensions that are somewhat more involved. In particular, we show that our labeling schemes with queries on trees can be extended to the dynamic scenario using model translation methods based on those of [42, 38]. In order to save in the message complexity, we needed to make some adaptations to those methods, as well as to one of the static routing schemes of [24]. Second, we show that the study of the queries model can help with the traditional model too. That is, using ideas from our routing labeling scheme with one query, we show how to construct a 3-approximation routing scheme without queries for unweighted trees in the fixed-port model with Î˜â¢(logâ¡n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(\log n)roman_Î˜ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels.

Finally, we turn to a non-distributed environment and demonstrate similar constructions. That is, first, we show a simple method to transform previous results on NCA queries on static and dynamic trees in order to support also distance queries. Then, we show that one can preprocess a general weighted graph using almost linear space so that flow queries can be answered in almost constant time.

2 Preliminaries

Let Tğ‘‡Titalic_T be a tree and let vğ‘£vitalic_v be a vertex in Tğ‘‡Titalic_T. Let dâ¢eâ¢gâ¢(v)ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘£deg(v)italic_d italic_e italic_g ( italic_v ) denote the degree of vğ‘£vitalic_v. In the case where the tree Tğ‘‡Titalic_T is weighted (respectively, unweighted), the depth of a vertex is defined as its weighted (resp., unweighted) distance to the root. The nearest common ancestor of uğ‘¢uitalic_u and wğ‘¤witalic_w, Nâ¢Câ¢Aâ¢(u,w)ğ‘ğ¶ğ´ğ‘¢ğ‘¤NCA(u,w)italic_N italic_C italic_A ( italic_u , italic_w ), is the common ancestor of both uğ‘¢uitalic_u and wğ‘¤witalic_w of maximum depth. Let ğ’¯â¢(n)ğ’¯ğ‘›{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) denote the family of all nğ‘›nitalic_n-node unweighted trees. Incoming and outgoing links from every node are identified by so called port-numbers. We distinguish between the following two variants of port models regarding routing schemes. In the designer port model the designer of the scheme can freely assign the port numbers of each vertex (as long as these port numbers are unique), and in the fixed-port model the port numbers at each vertex are assigned by an adversary. We assume that each port number is encoded using Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits.

2.2 Labeling schemes and cğ‘citalic_c-query labeling schemes

See Section 7 for alternative definition for query labeling schemes.

2.3 Routing schemes and Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximation routing schemes

A routing scheme is composed of a marker algorithm â„³â„³{\cal M}caligraphic_M for assigning each vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v of a graph GğºGitalic_G with a label â„³â¢(v)â„³ğ‘£{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ), coupled with a router algorithm â„›â„›{\cal R}caligraphic_R whose inputs are the header of a message, â„³â¢(v)â„³ğ‘£{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) and the label â„³â¢(y)â„³ğ‘¦{\cal M}(y)caligraphic_M ( italic_y ) of a destination vertex yğ‘¦yitalic_y. If a vertex xğ‘¥xitalic_x wishes to send a message to vertex yğ‘¦yitalic_y, it first prepares and attaches a header to the message. Then the router algorithm xğ‘¥xitalic_x outputs a port of xğ‘¥xitalic_x on which the message is delivered to the next vertex. This is repeated in every vertex until the message reaches the destination vertex yğ‘¦yitalic_y. Each intermediate vertex uğ‘¢uitalic_u on the route may replace the header of the message with a new header and may perform a local computation. The requirement is that the weighted length of resulting path connecting xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y is the same as the distance between xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y in GğºGitalic_G.

For a constant Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î², a Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximation routing scheme is the same as a routing scheme except that the requirement is that the length of resulting route connecting xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y is a Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximation for the distance between xğ‘¥xitalic_x and yğ‘¦yitalic_y in GğºGitalic_G.

In addition to the label size, we also measure a routing scheme (and a Î²ğ›½\betaitalic_Î²-approximation routing scheme) by the header size, i.e., the maximum number of bits used in a header of a message.

3 Labeling schemes with one query

In this section we demonstrate that the query model allows for significantly shorter labels. In particular, we describe simple 1-query labeling schemes with labels that beat the lower bounds in the following well studied cases: for the family of nğ‘›nitalic_n-node trees, schemes supporting the routing (in the fixed-port model), distance, separation level, and the id-NCA functions; for the family of nğ‘›nitalic_n-node general graphs, a scheme supporting the flow function. We note that all the schemes we present use asymptotically optimal labels. 5 Adapting the 1-query schemes on trees to the dynamic setting

In this section we show how to translate our 1-query labeling schemes on trees to the dynamic settings, i.e, to the leaf-increasing and leaf-dynamic tree models, [38, 42] (see also â€œRelated workâ€ in Section 1). In a dynamic scheme, the marker protocol updates the labels after every topological change. We show that the reduction in the label sizes obtained by introducing a single query in the dynamic scenario is similar to the reduction in the static case.

To describe the adaptation fully, we need to give many details about the methods of [42, 38, 24]. Unfortunately, this is not possible in this extended abstract. In our construction below, we just state and then use some facts about these methods. These facts can be proven easily given these methods.

The initial idea is to apply the methods introduced in [42, 38] to convert labeling schemes for static networks to work on dynamic networks too. Unfortunately, we cannot do this directly, since these methods were designed for traditional labeling schemes and not for 1-query labeling schemes.

The next idea is to perform the conversion indirectly. That is, recall (Section 3) that our 1-query labeling schemes utilize components that are schemes in the traditional model (with no queries). That is, some utilize Ï€Nâ¢Câ¢Asubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ´\pi_{NCA}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the label-NCA labeling scheme of [5] and some utilize Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the routing scheme of [24]. Hence, one can first convert these components to the dynamic setting. Second, one can attempt to use the resulted dynamic components in a similar way that we used the static components in Section 3. This turns out to be simple in the cases of the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions, but more involved in the case of the routing function.

In the case of the distance and separation level functions, Ï€Nâ¢Câ¢Asubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ´\pi_{NCA}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used together with the depth of each vertex in its label. Hence, in the dynamic case, we need to update the depth with every topological change. In the dynamic models above, this uses only a constant number of messages per topological change, since once a vertex is added, its depth remains the same.

However, when trying to translate our 1-query routing labeling scheme to the dynamic settings, things turn out to be more difficult. Informally, the reason is the following. In Ï†fâ¢iâ¢xsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\varphi_{fix}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, our static 1-query routing labeling scheme, each non-root vertex â€˜knowsâ€™ the label assigned to its parent by another static routing scheme Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Section 3). When this scheme is made dynamic, the natural translation that enables the child to continue to â€˜knowâ€™ the label of its parent is the following:
Notification: whenever the label of a non-leaf vertex changes, it notifies the new label to all the children. When a child receives such a notification message, it updates its Ï†fâ¢iâ¢xsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\varphi_{fix}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT label accordingly (see Section 3).

In order to have an efficient translation, we need to account for the messages used for the above notification. This turns out to be relatively cheap when using the translation method of [42]. The relevant facts about [42] is the following: Theorem 4.16 and the fact that the label of a vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v changes only as a part of changes in all the vertices of some subtree Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. These changes in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT involve Î©â¢(|Tâ€²|)Î©superscriptğ‘‡â€²\Omega(|T^{\prime}|)roman_Î© ( | italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ) messages anyhow (not including the new notification messages required from vğ‘£vitalic_v to its children). It so happened that in the method of [42], whenever a vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v is included in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, all its children are included in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well. Hence, the cost of the new notification messages can be amortized on the cost of the messages sent anyhow in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to perform the changes. Hence, we can (1) use the transformation of [42] to transform Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be dynamic, and then (2) use the new notification messages to implement Ï†fâ¢iâ¢xsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥\varphi_{fix}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the resulted dynamic version of Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This yields a dynamic routing scheme with 1-query enjoying the complexities promised in [42] (see part 2 in Theorem 5.1 below). It is still left to ensure parts 1 and 3 of Theorem 5.1 below. For that we need to use the transformation of [38], which turns out to be less easy.

To prove parts 1 and 3 of Theorem 5.1, the relevant fact about [38] consists of Theorems 1 and 2 of [38], and of the list of the cases where messages are sent. The latter is needed because we would like to show that we can amortize the cost of the new messages we now send, on the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. Unlike the case of [42], here messages are sent over a subtree that may include some vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v, but not all of its children. Recall that our modifications includes the notification: sending messages from vğ‘£vitalic_v, whose label was changed, to all of its children. When vğ‘£vitalic_v has children outside of Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we cannot amortize the cost of the notification messages on the cost of the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. It turns out, however, that the only vertex in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that not all of its children are necessarily in Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the root râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of Tâ€²superscriptğ‘‡â€²T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, the notifications messages sent by a vertex vâˆˆTâ€²ğ‘£superscriptğ‘‡â€²v\in T^{\prime}italic_v âˆˆ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where vâ‰ râ€²ğ‘£superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²v\neq r^{\prime}italic_v â‰  italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT do not increase the cost of the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. The only thing left to consider is the case where râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes its label in the dynamic labeling scheme given by the method of [38] applied on Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the static routing scheme of [24]. To bound the number of notification messages sent by râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we make sure that the label of râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes only when râ€²superscriptğ‘Ÿâ€²r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most 1 child. This is done by modifying the static routing scheme Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that when applying Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on any tree, the label given by Ï€dâ¢eâ¢ssubscriptğœ‹ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘ \pi_{des}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the root of the tree is always the same.

It therefore follows that the cost of the remaining notification messages can be amortized on the cost of the messages sent anyhow by [38]. The necessary modifications of the schemes, as well as the proof of the following theorem, appear in the appendix.

6 Applications in a non-distributed environments

In this section we first use ideas from our 1-query labeling schemes to translate previously known results on finding NCA in trees to support distance queries. We then use the translated scheme to show that general graphs can be preprocessed efficiently to support flow queries.

6.1 Distance queries in trees

Harel and Tarjan [36] describe a linear time algorithm to preprocess a tree and build a data structure allowing NCA queries to be answered in constant time on a RAM. Subsequently, simpler algorithms with better constant factors have been proposed in [53, 13, 28, 58, 14]. On a pointer machine, [36] show a lower bound of Î©â¢(logâ¡logâ¡n)Î©ğ‘›\Omega(\log\log n)roman_Î© ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) on the query time, which matches the upper bound of [60]. In the leaf-increasing tree model, [22, 10] show how to make updates in amortized constant time while keeping the constant worst-case query time on a RAM, or the Oâ¢(logâ¡logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) worst-case query time on a pointer machine. In [17] they show how to maintain the above mentioned results on a RAM in the leaf-dynamic tree model with worst case constant update. See [5] for a survey.

Simply by adding a pointer from each vertex to its depth and using Equation 1, we obtain the following lemma.

Lemma 6.1

The results of [36, 53, 13, 28, 58, 14, 36, 60, 22, 10, 17] can be translated to support either distance queries or separation level queries (instead of NCA queries).

We note that other types of dynamic models were studied in the non-distributed environment regarding NCA queries. See, for example, [17, 10]. However, in these types of topological changes, our transformation to distance queries is not efficient since any such changes may effect the depth of too many vertices.

7 Conclusion and open problems

In this paper we demonstrate that considering the labels of three vertices, instead of two, can lead to a significant reduction in the sizes of the labels. Inspecting two labels, and inspecting three, are approaches that lie on one end of a spectrum. On the other end of the spectrum would be a representation for which the decoder inspects the labels of all the nodes before answering (nğ‘›nitalic_n-query labeling schemes). It is not hard to show that for any graph family â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F on nğ‘›nitalic_n node graphs, and for many functions (for example, distance or adjacency), one can construct an nğ‘›nitalic_n-query labeling scheme on â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F using asymptotically optimal labels, i.e, logâ¡|â„±|/n+Î˜â¢(logâ¡n)â„±ğ‘›Î˜ğ‘›\log|{\cal F}|/n+\Theta(\log n)roman_log | caligraphic_F | / italic_n + roman_Î˜ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels (though the decoder may not be polynomial). The idea behind such a scheme is to enumerate the graphs in â„±â„±{\cal F}caligraphic_F arbitrarily. Then, given some Gâˆˆâ„±ğºâ„±G\in{\cal F}italic_G âˆˆ caligraphic_F whose number in this enumeration is iğ‘–iitalic_i, distribute the binary representation of iğ‘–iitalic_i among the vertices of GğºGitalic_G. In this way, given the labels of all nodes, the decoder can reconstruct the graph and answer the desired query. Therefore, a natural question is to examine other points in this spectrum, i.e, examine cğ‘citalic_c-query labeling schemes for 1<c<n1ğ‘ğ‘›1<c<n1 < italic_c < italic_n.

There are other dimensions to the above question. For example, by our definition, given the labels of two vertices, the cğ‘citalic_c vertices that are chosen by the query algorithm Qğ‘„Qitalic_Q are chosen simultaneously. Alternatively, one may define a possibly stronger model in which these cğ‘citalic_c vertices are chosen one by one, i.e., the next vertex is determined using the knowledge obtained from the labels of previous vertices.

A.5 Sketch of the Proof of Theorem 5.1

The proof presented here in not completely self contained. A truely complete proof would include many details concerning three papers, namely, [24] and especially [42] and [38], and is, thus, too long to be given here.

We divide the proof into two parts. In the first part we consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions and in the second part we consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query routing labeling scheme.

A.5.1 First part of the proof

Let us first consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions. This part follows rather naturally from [42, 38].

Recall that in a query labeling scheme, the label of each vertex is composed of two sublabels, the index sublabel and the data sublabel. In our (static) 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions, the index sublabel of each vertex vğ‘£vitalic_v is simply the label assigned to vğ‘£vitalic_v by Ï€Nâ¢Câ¢Asubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ´{\pi}_{NCA}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the label-NCA labeling scheme of [5], and the data sublabel of vğ‘£vitalic_v is either vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s depth or vğ‘£vitalic_vâ€™s identity. Therefore, we can dynamically maintain the index sublabel of each vertex using Ï€^Nâ¢Câ¢Asubscript^ğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ´\hat{\pi}_{NCA}over^ start_ARG italic_Ï€ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the dynamic label-NCA labeling scheme resulted by applying either Theorem 4.16 of [42] or Theorems 1 and 2 of [38] on Ï€Nâ¢Câ¢Asubscriptğœ‹ğ‘ğ¶ğ´{\pi}_{NCA}italic_Ï€ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
